column3: Details
Conformance to EARS pattern
Responsible entity as the subject
Use subject and verb appropriate to the entity
Define all the terms in an associated glossary
Use `the' instead of `a' or `an'
Consistent units with common measurement system
E.g., `some', `relevant', `typical' and adverbs
E.g.,`if necessary', `as appropriate', `as required'
E.g., `including but not limited to', `and so on'
E.g., `to be able to', `to allow', `to enable'
Use a separate clause for each condition/qualification
Use grammatically correct sentences
Use correct spelling
Use correct and fewer punctuation
Use a defined convention for logical expressions
Avoid negation in requirements
Do not use the oblique (`/') symbol
Single sentence qualified by relevant sub-clauses
E.g., `and', `then', `or', `but', `whether'
Avoid intent/reason, e.g., `... because ...', `... to ...'
Avoid subordinate text
Avoid using a group noun to name the set
Refer to relevant figure/diagram/model
Avoid personal and indefinite pronouns
Avoid relying on headings to get context
E.g., `100\%', `all', `always', `never'
State conditions’ applicability explicitly
Multiple conditions for single action is better
According to the aspects of the problem or system
Express each requirement once and only once
Avoid stating implementation in a requirement
Use `each' instead of `all', `any' or `both'
Define each quantity with a range of values
Provide specific measurable performance targets
Instead of indefinite ones: `until', `simultaneous'
Consistent across the project’s lifecycle and ontology
Consistent throughout requirements and the lifecycle
Avoid in requirements, models and lifecycle artefacts
Use a project-wide style guide for all requirements
Use a consistent format and number of signification digits
Group related requirements together
Conform to a template for organizing requirements
